headline: Vegetarian Mexican Inspired Stuffed Peppers
description: Green bell peppers are stuffed with rice, chili-style tomatoes, and Mexican cheese blend, creating a hearty and not-too-spicy vegetarian dinner the whole family will love.

video.description: The classic stuffed bell pepper hot dish.
video.name: Mexican Stuffed Peppers

name: Vegetarian Mexican Inspired Stuffed Peppers
recipeIngredient: 4 large green bell peppers - tops, seeds, and membranes removed
1 (15 ounce) can black beans, drained and rinsed
1 (8 ounce) package shredded Mexican cheese blend (such as Sargento® Authentic Mexican)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Bring a large pot of water and 1 tablespoon salt to a boil. Add green bell peppers and cook until slightly softened, 3 to 4 minutes.
Drain bell peppers and arrange cut-side up in a 9x9-inch baking dish.
Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add onion; cook and stir until softened, 5 to 10 minutes.

Transfer cooked onion into a large bowl; add rice, black beans, and tomatoes. Stir in chili powder, garlic salt, cumin, and 1/2 teaspoon salt until well combined. Fold in 1 1/2 cups Mexican cheese blend.
Spoon rice mixture evenly into bell peppers; sprinkle with remaining Mexican cheese blend.
Bake in the preheated oven until cheese is melted and bubbling, about 30 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Was easy and tasted fabulous
Very tasty and easy to make. It was a hit at our brunch!
I have way way too much rice left over and not enough peppers I guess I have to make them in to burritos?
I used 1.5 Cups of my homemade bean/corn salsa instead of the chili tomatoes and Cheddar cheese. Made filling for about 6 bell peppers. My son liked these a lot.

I made it the first time exactly what the recipe called. So good! Second time I chopped the peppers instead of stuffing them and used it in burritos. Third time I didn't have peppers, so I cubed a cabbage. I honestly think the cabbage adds the perfect crunch and I like it much better. This is such an easy recipe for big families that you can edit as needed.
It turned out really good. Will definitely make this again!
Delicious, the whole family loved it. I didn’t have Ro-tell style tomatoes but my family doesn’t like spicy so I used a partial can of red gold crushed tomatoes… was very good
These are awesome, I baked my red bell pepper in the oven 1st rather than boiling it and I also added smoked pepperika and tapped it with cheddar cheese. it was incredible!

Excellent recipe, I’ll make this frequently!

I substituted riced cauliflower for the rice, and used Rotel Hot Habanero tomatoes, plus 1-1/2 cups of no salt tomato sauce to the recipe. I left out the added salt, but may add some next time to bring out the tomato flavor a bit more. As others said, this makes quite a bit of filling! I’ll use the extra in low-carb tortillas. Only 6 points on WW!

This would also be yummy with some ground chicken breast added in for extra protein.
Loved this recipe, I used quinoa in place of rice. The stuffing alone would make a great side dish!
Easy to make and delicious. I actually found it easier to use one packet of dried taco mix instead of all the other seasonings. Besides that I made exactly how it stated. Definitely will make again!
Delicious! Easy to make and I love the flavors. I used petite tomatoes w/ jalapeños which adds a little kick!
I added corn and a bit of extra cumin and they turned out great. I’ve also made with quinoa instead of rice and they were great!

Came out great! I roasted the bell peppers for about 20 minutes vs boiling. I only had cotija cheese so I threw that in. Threw in a can of corn and fire roasted tomatoes. I mixed everything in the pan that sautéed the onions. I was able to fill 5 bell peppers. Served with chicken enchiladas.
So good , for husband added some meat but made made just as directed
So easy! Even my two year old liked it. I did't boil the peppers though, i just filled the and put them straight in the oven. I also added an 8 ounce can of tomato sauce.

I loved these! I used both red and green peppers and used a combination of cheddar and pepper jack cheeses for the cheese in them. I ended up with a lot of extra innards, so I would suggest preparing 6 peppers when you make it not 4.
I have made this recipe several times. My husband loves it. I used the microwave ready Spanish rice once, because I didn’t have time to cook rice. That variation had a great flavor also. Great recipe
This is such an easy recipe and full of flavor. I’ve made it multiple times. The only thing I would add is more peppers, 4 just isn’t enough. I always have way more filling.

Excellent! Followed almost exactly, but with unseasoned diced tomatoes and sharp cheddar cheese, so threw in a little more cumin and some cayenne pepper. Also, sautéed some of the pepper tops (chopped) that were sliced off along, a few chopped mushrooms and with minced garlic with the onions. I used yellow and red peppers (that's what I had). I also had quite a bit of filling leftover and am enjoying them as a filler in tortillas a few days later! A tad of sour cream on top makes it even better!
This recipe was delicious. I did not pre boil the peppers, instead I added about 3/4 inch of water on the bottom of the baking pan prior to baking and they were perfect.
SOOO GOOD i personally made with with taco meat, spanish rice and added a little bit of queso in the mix of everything and it was delicious everyone loved it
Super easy and good. I added corn, green onions, and fresh garlic. Made it a little spicier.
it was good. I made it as is (I didn't have chili powder, so I used paprika) but I didn't think the rice wasn't flavorful enough for me.

I added a can of diced tomatoes and jalapeños to the bottom of the dish and I replaced the beans with plant based crumbles (faux ground beef). It was delicious! My mom who is not interested in vegetarian main dishes at all loved it so did my 11 year old working n eating more plant based food and this is a keeper!
We loved this dinner. Works best with green bell peppers, but it was fun to try it in red and orange.

I used Quesidilla cheese and Sharp Cheddar. Otherwise followed the recipe to the T. It was really delicious!
A keeper for sure!
Enjoyed this very much. I didn't find it at all dry but for my own taste will leave out the cheese next time. A worthy alternative to beef and rice stuffed peppers.

This is fabulous! I hate to make adjustments the first time I make something because I then question how accurate my review is but, based on several reviews, I made a few adjustments (some out of necessity & some because of personal preference) but I think this recipe is foolproof. It will become a regular in our house.
So, based on previous reviews, I made the following changes: 1) I used quinoa instead of rice to add more protein; 2) I pre-baked the peppers instead of boiling them since that was easier (350-degrees for 15-20 minutes); 3) Sautéed the onions & 3 cloves of garlic instead of garlic salt because I prefer real garlic; 4) Couldn't find tomatoes w/chili in store so used plain petite cut tomatoes and added a bit more chili powder and 1/2 jar of salsa. I wanted to make 6 servings instead of 4 so made more Quinoa thinking I would need it. No! I only needed 2 C of quinoa & the half jar of salsa and I had enough for 7 or 8 peppers. I use the extra to as a rolled tortilla for a quick and easy lunch. This is fantastic! Thank you for sharing.

Liked this a lot. I used yellow peppers, and riced cauliflower. I also diced up the usable pieces of the pepper tops and sauteed with the onions. I only had a can of plain tomatoes, so I added a fresh, diced jalapeno pepper. I cooked the tomatoes down with the vegetables, and added some red enchilada sauce into the mix and into the baking dish.

I made a few changes based on what I have on hand and my own preferences. I used cheddar cheese because it’s what I had. I also added jalapeños to my onion mixture because I love spicy. The biggest change is that I substituted quinoa for rice because it offers more protein and less carbs. I still have the same flavor profile and really enjoyed this dish
This is now a staple in our house. My meat and potatoes loving husband enjoys this dish and my two year old gobbles it up.

This is certainly my go to dish when I'm tired and can't stand to be in the kitchen for a long time. I made some alterations to the dish. Added whole cumin the oil and then added garlic ,onion and other ingredients. Added just half a tablespoon dry basil powder for that earthy aroma. I layered the rice within the pepper and added just a little bit of home made pesto sauce along with the cheese while layering and there was this delicious recipe ready ! Thanks for sharing this wonderful recipe
It was good

This was great! I actually threw the sliced and pitted peppers in the oven for about 12 mins instead of boiling them since the oven was heating up anyway. Otherwise, I followed the recipe exactly and really enjoyed it. I will double the stuffing next time so my kids can eat that. Unfortunately, they are not fans of the pepper.
I had corn left over brown rice, but I used all the spices and steps without the beans. Pretty good. If you have a surplus of peppers, it would make a terrific pot -luck offering.
Best stuffed pepper recipe I ever made! Thank you!
everyone loved them used cauliflower rice
Really good! The rice filling inside the pepper is dish by itself.
I used normal diced tomato's instead of caned, but I tried my best to stick with the recipe and it was so good everyone loves it, I would totally make it again.
I increase the spice level a wee bit and slice the bell peppers lengthwise to make them easier to eat. Otherwise, I follow the recipe as is. It's excellent!

I used a rice/quinoa blend instead of regular rice. Though I know the recipe was vegetarian based, I decided to add garlic flavored pork. I removed three pork sausage links from their casings, browned the meat and crumbled it, and then added it to the bell pepper stuffing mixture. My son ate the extra stuffing, because there was more than was needed to stuff the four peppers. My family absolutely loved it. Definitely a keeper.

This was great! I didn't have any of the cheese suggested, so I just added more chili powder and used cheddar cheese. There was so much filling (or maybe my peppers were small), so I was able to bake the rest it on its own in a loaf tin, which just added to the meal. Awesome and easy!
It was an amazing recipe and I would definitely make them again. The only changes I made was adding corn.
These were delicious. I'm not a fan of green peppers so I substituted with red ans orange bell instead.
Amazing how these spices blend together. It is a very tasty and satisfying dish that is more than hearty enough for a full meal.

Take note: the 1 tbsp of salt is for the WATER to cook the peppers, not for the tomato/beans/rice mix! Accidentally mixed them up. 
Despite the salt overload, the final product tasted pretty good.
I substituted the rice for quinoa and it turned out amazing. My recommendation would also be to put any extra stuffing mix into the pan around the peppers. I’d also add corn.
This recipe is perfect except I halved the cumin. Everyone loved it! I had to find something meatless and gluten free and this fit the bill. I served it with garlic bread.

Everything about this is wonderful I added 1/2 cup taco sauce
and also served taco sauce with the peppers. My husband
and I both loved them.
I loved this! I used both green and yellow peppers and found the yellow peppers were sweeter and had more flavor in my opinion. But both were good, nonetheless!
It was a good starting recipe. It was dryer and milder than I expected. Increased the spice quantities and added tomato sauce for the second half. Will make again.

My fiance loves hot food, but no one else in the family can stomach things that are too spicy. I made the mistake of grabbing a can of Rotel and it was way too spicy for the family. Everyone at theirs except for my daughter, but all the leftovers will be exclusively for Tony. I thought it tasted really good, and I will make it again and I won't mess up and get Rotel next time.

I used Quinoa instead of rice as I had just cooked a batch of it. I used plain water to boil the peppers, used fresh garlic and omitted the salt and it was still plenty salty for me with the salt in the canned tomato and beans. Plus I did substitute some canned corn for part of the quinoa. Used dairy free cheese as milk bothers my allergies. Was very good but tricky to eat so since we had to chop it up on the plate decided next time I will just forget stuffing the peppers, just dice them up and make a casserole! I used all organic ingredients so was a successful vegan meal! Even my picky husband liked it!

I made a resolution to eat vegetarian at least one or two days a week and this was the first recipe I tried. Absolutely delicious! I used shredded sharp cheddar since I always have some of that on hand for omelets, otherwise followed recipe. Hopefully I can find a few more veggie dished as good as this one!

This was 5 stars with my changes, as copied from other users. I baked the peppers at 350 for 15 minutes and this was a game-changer. It mellowed out the flavor and softened them up for my family who doesn't love peppers as much. I used a clove of garlic with the onion, used brown rice, increased cumin to 1 tsp, and instead of the can of tomato sauce, I had some leftover Aldi brand spaghetti sauce and put at least a 1/2 cup in the rice mixture and more on top before baking. This sweetened it up a bit, but it was so yummy. I've made several variations of stuffed peppers and this so far was the family's favorite!

I added 2tsp. crushed red pepper, 1 tsp. Creole seasoning, and in place of the garlic salt I used 1rsp. salt and 3 cloves of garlic. I also added a small handful of frozen corn. I then sautéd the onion, added the garlic, then added the spices and remaining ingredients. I put half the cheese in the mixture, and the remainder on top of the peppers.
Really tasty recipe! Makes a lot, so I was able to portion out and freeze for future meals.
The filling was delicious. My guests seemed to enjoy it.

This was my first time eating stuffed peppers. I was a bit nervous. I shouldn't have been as they were delicious! I added spicy sausage and some hot sauce in the mixture. Next time I'm going to turn it into a casserole with the peppers already cut as it's a pain to do once the full stuff pepper is cooked and on your plate.

I made this last night and it was good, but the peppers should have boiled longer. The mixture was good too, I added more seasoning to my liking than what was on here because it just tasted bland if I hadn't. And the mixture could have fixed for at least 6, maybe a couple more, so I have a huge bowl left over that I don't know what to do with.
Substituted riced cauliflower to keep carbs low. Real easy to make, garnished with green onions and sour cream.

I will make this again and again! I added spices to our taste.
 Then I doubled the rice and bean mix so I had enough to also fill corn tortillas in a 9x13 pan for a Mexican casserole of sorts. We gladly munched on it all week!
I would share on with someone else next time, or use smaller peppers because it was just way too much of the pepper taste.
I prepared it and then something came up and I couldn’t cook it right away. I put it in the fridge overnight and popped it in the oven for dinner the next night, it was great!

These were delicious! My husband was a little leery because he had never had stuffed peppers without meat before, but he liked them so much that he ate 4. 
I did change it up a little and used a couple of fresh tomatoes from the garden and a can of tomato sauce. I also added a couple of jalapenos and fresh garlic. 
I liked to pre-boil method and I didn't think the flavor of the peppers suffered as a result. The texture of the peppers were just right, not too soft. 
We will definitely be making these again.
I loved this recipe and so did my 2 year old! Definitely will be making it again!
we made a few changes just added a bag of frozen bag of veggies
Easy and good! Added corn and quinoa but so versatile you could add/subtract with whatever you have on hand !
Loved the recipe and easy to follow - I added spinach(which I love) DELICIOUS!
These peppers were great. Had to use leftover salsa for tomatoes and it gave the filling a little kick. Thank you for the recipe - Jannie
Used fresh plum tomatoes (3) and added fresh garlic to fry with the onions
I cut the rice to 1 cup, then added a can of red beans.
very satisfying dish
very satisfying dish
I used chipotle chili pepper instead of chili pepper. I also added canned corn and used Hunt's Fire Roasted Diced Tomatoes
A hit with vegetarians and meat eaters alike. Will definitely be making this again. Froze a few and they were great a month later.
These turned out delicious! I didn’t use nearly as much cheese as the recipe called for and they turned out amazing all the same. :)
I put roasted organic corn and green chiles and some cheese in mix before stuffing with more cheese on top. Marvelous for this vegetarian of 26 years to find such a great recipe. Well done!
This was so easy and good!!
Fantastic!!!

I used 8 ounces of pepper jack cheese for the filling. I added a lot of cilantro. I added 1 can of green chili tomatoes and chopped of bunch of vine ripe tomatoes. I cooked real garlic with the onions and did not use garlic salt. I also had a bunch of other mexicain spices I used instead. I topped it with cheddar cheese.
I put the chopped onions, and some carrot, celery, and kale in with the rice to cook so I didn't dirty an extra pan! Turned out great!
We all loved it when I made it a few months ago and I am making it again this week!

Used leftover cooked quinoa instead of rice and it was FABULOUS. Baked bells at 250 for 25 minutes as others suggested (instead of boiling). I may try boiling next time, because they were a bit crisp, but still delish. Thanks for the recipe!

Loved this recipe!

I subbed the chili diced tomatoes for a can of just regular diced tomatoes and I subbed the rice for one bag of Uncle Ben’s quinoa and brown rice bag. 

Oh, and to save time in the oven. After I drained the pot with the peppers in it I used that pot for all the remaining ingredients (minus cheese) and cooked. Added cheese then stuffed the peppers . Oven only took 15 minutes or so to melt the cheese.
I mashed the black beans before mixing the rest of the ingredients and the consistency came out excellent! Great recipe

I have made these a few times now and are always a huge hit. I use 6 peppers and there is enough filling to fill another 3 more for sure. I also don't add the cheese in with the mixture I layer it in peppers and on top.

These were delish! Super easy to make, although it did take a number of dishes. I put in just a smidge of extra spices (all on the recipe, just more) and the filling tasted a bit spicy, but great ... but after baking with cheese, it all mellowed out. Next time, more spice, but still great!
We absolutely loved making this. So delicious!

Delicious I modified the recipe after reading the reviews I baked peppers instead of boiling and I substituted Quinoa instead of Rice and I added Ground Turkey. I will make it again I used 4 peppers but had enough for at least 2-3 more
Delicious and I also used corn as an added ingredient and brown rice instead of white rice. You can't go wrong with this recipe especially if you tweek it and add some of your own ingredients.
I used red peppers and they were great too!
My veggie husband loved it! Next time I will add some bits like corn and perhaps drizzle it with more cheese..

I like many others change this recipe a little bitI used yellow peppers because It’s my favorite of the three colors and it has a lighter taste to it. I like many others change this recipe a little bit.

I like them and so does my 9 year old. I did add garlic in with the onions. I also added shrimp in on another batch. Because I had a hard time getting mine to stand on their own, I used my muffin pan and that worked out great. Because the first time I made it I had so much rice mixture left over, I put the rest of it in soft shells. Kids really liked that too. I’ve made this twice already and it will be a regular in my house.
Super easy and super delicious! All kids loved it (10-16 years old).
Quite good, fast and easy to make, but needs more flavour. This recipe is a good jumping off point.
Turned out great!!! No variations.
